DataElement.preferredDefinition: A distinguishable class of toxic substances usually causing unwanted side effects in the lung.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border._Having to do with poison or something harmful to the body. Toxic substances usually cause unwanted side effects._The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with poison or something harmful to the body. Toxic substances usually cause unwanted side effects. :The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with poison or something harmful to the body. Toxic substances usually cause unwanted side effects.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border._The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The airborne components that result from the combustion of diesel fuel. It includes both gaseous products of complete and incomplete combustion and particulates.

Concepts.definition: The airborne components that result from the combustion of diesel fuel. It includes both gaseous products of complete and incomplete combustion and particulates.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fine powder derived by the crushing of coal.

Concepts.definition: Fine powder derived by the crushing of coal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural compound of silicon and oxygen found mostly in sand, Silica has three main crystalline varieties: quartz, tridymite, and cristobalite. Fine particulate silica dust from quartz rock causes over a long-term progressive lung injury, silicosis. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: A natural compound of silicon and oxygen found mostly in sand, Silica has three main crystalline varieties: quartz, tridymite, and cristobalite. Fine particulate silica dust from quartz rock causes over a long-term progressive lung injury, silicosis. (NCI04)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radioactive element with atomic symbol U, atomic number 92, and atomic weight 238.

Concepts.definition: A radioactive element with atomic symbol U, atomic number 92, and atomic weight 238.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An element with atomic symbol Rn, atomic number 86, and 222.0.

Concepts.definition: An element with atomic symbol Rn, atomic number 86, and 222.0.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.
